body_html:
I know it's only one guy's opinion, but I actually really preferred the old printout all around. I see you guys moving to be more like NumPy and TensorFlow with this change, but I actually find it harder to infer the axis I'm looking at based on brackets a la

tensor([[ 2.,  6.,  5.,  4.,  3.,  0.,  5.,  4.,  7.,  3.,  4.,  7.,
          6.,  3.,  7.,  4.,  6.,  0.,  3.,  4.],
        [ 3.,  6.,  0.,  2.,  6.,  0.,  4.,  6.,  0.,  1.,  0.,  1.,
          3.,  0.,  2.,  3.,  2.,  4.,  0.,  2.]], device='cuda:0')

than I did when they were explicitly described in the printing as they were <0.4. Just my few cents.

I know it's only one guy's opinion, but I actually really preferred the old printout all around. I see you guys moving to be more like NumPy and TensorFlow with this change, but I actually find it harder to infer the axis I'm looking at based on brackets a la
tensor([[ 2.,  6.,  5.,  4.,  3.,  0.,  5.,  4.,  7.,  3.,  4.,  7.,

than I did when they were explicitly described in the printing as they were <0.4. Just my few cents.
body:
I know it's only one guy's opinion, but I actually really preferred the old printout all around. I see you guys moving to be more like NumPy and TensorFlow with this change, but I actually find it harder to infer the axis I'm looking at based on brackets a la

```
tensor([[ 2.,  6.,  5.,  4.,  3.,  0.,  5.,  4.,  7.,  3.,  4.,  7.,
          6.,  3.,  7.,  4.,  6.,  0.,  3.,  4.],
        [ 3.,  6.,  0.,  2.,  6.,  0.,  4.,  6.,  0.,  1.,  0.,  1.,
          3.,  0.,  2.,  3.,  2.,  4.,  0.,  2.]], device='cuda:0')
```

than I did when they were explicitly described in the printing as they were <0.4. Just my few cents.
